transformed_texts:
I think the Catholic Church could benefit from some changes, especially in how they view certain issues.  I've heard that the Church is losing followers, and I think it might be because they aren't very accepting of things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. The Church has strong opinions on these topics, and while that's understandable, their stances feel a bit outdated.

If they were more open to modern ways of thinking, I think they wouldn't have to worry as much about losing people.  Many people are starting to disagree with the Church's views on these subjects, particularly when it comes to things like abortion and gay marriage.  Someone who believes in those things might not feel comfortable in a community that condemns them. For example, if someone supports abortion rights, they might not feel welcome in a Church that considers it completely wrong. Same goes for those who support gay marriage.

Personally, I don't see why they can't have female priests or allow priests to be married.  I'm not sure if those changes would have prevented past scandals, but it seems like a reasonable idea.

The Church says priests are "married" to God and devote their lives to Him, but everyone else has a job and a family life.  Why can't priests have both?

I'm not against gay marriage. I believe people shouldn't be judged for who they love, whether they're born that way or not. It's not a choice anyone makes. So, I think it's unfair to say that a man and a woman can marry, but two people of the same sex can't. Honestly, I haven't given this topic a lot of thought, but I definitely think it's wrong to deny same-sex couples the right to marry.   

I think being gay is just part of who a person is, like being straight. People aren't choosing to be gay, it's how they're born. It's not right to hold someone responsible for their sexual orientation.

I also don't think the federal government should be involved. It's not a legal or moral issue, in my opinion. I don't think it's appropriate for the government to dictate who can and can't marry. It's a personal matter.

It just seems wrong to me to treat gay people differently or make them feel like they've made a wrong choice.  They should be treated equally and allowed to live their lives how they choose.

I truly believe that gay marriage should be legal. Honestly, there's not a solid reason against it.  Some folks worry that gay couples threaten traditional families, but that's just not true. It's totally different.  Think of it like two sides of the same coin, heads and tails are different, but they're still connected.  Gay relationships are similar to straight ones, with the same hopes, dreams, and challenges.   

There are also important rights at stake.  For example, if you're in a gay relationship, your partner might not be able to make medical decisions for you if you're sick, or even visit you in the hospital, because they aren't legally recognized as family. That seems unfair if you're committed to spending your life with someone.  

And studies show that gay couples are just as successful as straight couples. They have the same things that make relationships work: love, communication, and support.  It's about the relationship, not who's involved.

The core issue is that people often get hung up on the idea of a religious ceremony. Gay couples aren't demanding a church wedding, they're asking for a legal document from the government: a marriage certificate.  If we separate church and state, then this shouldn't be a problem. It's like saying you can't have a civil union because it goes against your religion, but then you're okay with a marriage license. It's "separate but unequal."

I hear worries about adoption and community impact, especially about how kids raised by gay parents will be treated.  But ultimately, loving parents raise happy, well-adjusted kids, regardless of their sexual orientation. It's about good parenting, not about who the parents are.

I think the federal government should definitely step in and make gay marriage legal everywhere.  It's about basic equality. President Bush has strong beliefs about this issue, which seem connected to his views on abortion and stem cell research. Many arguments against gay marriage are based on religion, but morality is subjective and changes over time. Forcing one group's beliefs on everyone else is unfair and hypocritical, especially when we have a pledge of allegiance that includes "under God" yet oppose religious influence in government.

Some people believe being gay is a psychological defect or caused by childhood trauma, but the American Psychological Association has debunked that myth.  It's important to rely on science and research, not just personal opinions or cultural norms. If we all listened to experts and challenged our biases, the world would be a better place.

Okay, so I work in a hospital pharmacy during the summer, and it's made me think a lot about drugs.  I mean, just because something's illegal doesn't automatically mean it's bad. Take marijuana, for example.  It's illegal, but I think people should be able to use it for medical reasons. I'm not saying everyone should be smoking weed, but if it can help someone, why not?  It's not like those strong painkillers, like oxycodone, Vicodin, or Percocet, which are totally legal even though they can be addictive.  I see how those are helpful, so why not give marijuana a chance?  I think people get hung up on the stigma around marijuana, but it's not as harmful as everyone makes it out to be.  It's not like heroin or cocaine.  It wouldn't hurt to at least explore its potential benefits, especially for medical use. 

Maybe we should make it legal gradually, so people can learn to use it responsibly.  If we just keep demonizing it, it'll always be associated with bad things.  If we could change that image, maybe people would be more open to using it safely and for good.

I think the Catholic Church has changed to fit modern times. It's not as strict as it used to be. When I was younger, I went to church every Sunday dressed up in cute dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. I went to a private school, so I saw all my friends there on weekends.  Now that I'm older, they have a special mass for teenagers that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially in the summer, sometimes even coming straight from the beach. Even at the morning masses, where I used to always dress up, people wear jeans and khakis. It's a lot more relaxed.

I think that's the biggest change I've noticed. That's the church I know. I don't know about the church's internal politics, but that's the main thing that stands out to me.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests about pedophilia, I don't think allowing priests to marry or ordaining women would have stopped it. Some married men become pedophiles too, and their attraction to young children isn't caused by their marital status. It's the person, not their relationship status.

Becoming a priest is a choice, and there are other religions that allow priests to marry, like the one on the TV show "Seventh Heaven." If someone really wants to practice their faith and be married, they could consider a different religion.

(laughs)
You know, at first, I was okay with the idea of the Iraq War, but I think everyone was still shaken up from the 9/11 attacks. It felt like we went into Iraq with a bunch of justifications that didn't quite add up. The Bush administration kept tying the war to Osama Bin Laden and 9/11, saying Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. We now know that was all a lie.  That really bugs me, and the whole Iraq War just makes my blood boil.

It feels like the Bush administration straight-up lied to the American people, and they've never admitted it. Even Colin Powell, who gave that big speech at the UN, now says he wasn't really convinced by the evidence when he was presenting it. To me, that's a serious abuse of power. It's almost like an impeachable offense to lie to the people like that.  I think the Bush administration has completely disregarded the Constitution and has been trying to weaken it ever since 9/11. It seems like they came into office wanting to go to war.

There was this Treasury Secretary - I can't remember his name - who basically said that in his book after he got pushed out of his job. Seems like the younger Bush wanted revenge against Saddam Hussein because of his dad's administration, and he probably wanted to control Iraq's oil, too.  That's a pretty sneaky way to do things.

Look, I think the war has gone on long enough. Pulling out right now would probably create chaos, though, and more people would die.  There's this idea now of a coalition of countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia coming in to try and restore order, but I'm not sure that's a good idea either. It could cause even more problems because it'll mess with Iraq's sovereignty.

The news reports say that the Iraqi Parliament isn't really working. The Prime Minister doesn't seem to have any real power, and this guy, Muqtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting not long ago, now has at least 20 seats in Parliament. We're still dealing with all these different radical groups fighting for control, and it's causing a lot of tension.

(laughs)
I can't really say more about it without getting into some pretty sensitive stuff.

I'm not really sure what to say about the war in Iraq. It feels pointless because it wasn't even officially declared. It feels like it was just retaliation for 9/11, like we were trying to get back at Iraq because they were thought to be responsible.  I'm not really knowledgeable about the details of the war, but it seems like we're staying there to try and build a democracy, kind of like making Iraq another U.S. state, and also to access their oil. But staying there just makes everyone angry. 

Trying to force democracy on them is going to take forever, and if we leave, they'll be upset because things will be in chaos. It's a really tough situation. 

Honestly, I'm not even sure how I feel about it. I think maybe it's better to stay and try to help, but it's also wasting our resources and making our president look bad. 

It's like the Vietnam War, which was also an undeclared war and is now seen as meaningless. I worry that this war will be remembered the same way.  

There are families with sons and daughters in Iraq, and I want them to come home safe, but at the same time, we've disrupted their lives and culture. We're trying to force our way of life on them, which could make things worse and fuel more hatred towards the U.S. 

This whole situation is going to drag on for years and years.

I really don't think it's right for the government to make it legal or for a state to declare it as legal. I believe it's up to the churches because the Constitution clearly states separation of church and state. It's plainly written, and I feel that trying to enforce any kind of control over it would be going against what's already been established in the Constitution.  So, when people try to make it illegal, I think they're favoring one church's beliefs over others. As we can see, most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for in some areas like Boston.  But I don't think it's the government's place to decide what churches can and can't do. 

Separation of church and state is a key part of the Constitution and what allows for religious tolerance in the United States. Even though they were considering making an amendment, I think that would be completely wrong and contradictory to what's already been written. Plus, I believe it would be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I just don't think it's right.

I don't believe the federal government, or any government, should be involved in this issue. I don't understand why someone would push for this amendment unless it's because it goes against their personal beliefs as a Catholic. Like I said, his push for this amendment shows that he prefers one religion over others. I truly feel that it's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government officials. There isn't a good reason to support this amendment other than personal views. I don't see how it would impact the economy or anything else. In fact, it might have a positive impact on society.

Okay, so the war in Iraq...  I don't think the government was totally honest with us about why we went to war. They tried to tie it to 9/11, even though those two things weren't really connected. It felt like they were trying to use our anger after the attacks to justify the invasion, which started in 2003.

 Personally, I'm against war, especially starting wars preemptively.  This whole Iraq thing feels a lot like Vietnam. We should have learned from our mistakes there. 

So many American soldiers have died. They went in and just overthrew the Iraqi government, but they weren't prepared for what would happen next. They didn't understand the power vacuum and the chaos that would follow. They basically tried to install a democracy, similar to what they did in Vietnam, but it's  a long and tough process. 

You can't just force democracy on a country. It takes time, and it's messy. They made it seem like it would be a quick win, but it hasn't been. We've been there for years, and American troops are still dying. We're still trying to train Iraqi police and soldiers to take control of their own country. 

 It's a tough situation.  We've been there so long, how can we just leave now?  But how many more American lives are we willing to risk for this?  And honestly, it feels like this was more about oil than about democracy.  We knew Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but we haven't found any. Yet we're not doing anything about other countries with WMDs, like North Korea.  

I just hope it ends soon and that there's peace in Iraq someday.

Let me tell you, I've always been in favor of gay marriage. I truly believe it's a personal preference, something that science is increasingly showing might even have a biological basis rather than being just a social construct. It just doesn't seem right to deny people rights based on something they can't control.  It feels downright inhumane to me.  

I've always championed the cause of gay marriage. Politics and government shouldn't have a say in this. It's a personal matter, something that happens within families and communities.  

In my own neighborhood, there are a few openly gay couples who aren't married because they can't be. They live their lives just like any other family – walking dogs, going about their day. They're just like everyone else.

It's frustrating to see someone like Bush trying to play God and define marriage in a way that suits his beliefs. To me, it's completely ridiculous.

What I find interesting is that research suggests being gay might be linked to things happening in our brains, a biological predisposition rather than something learned from our environment. It's not about growing up with lots of sisters or a missing father figure. It's about who you are.

The whole situation is just strange. A couple can get married without anyone knowing if they're a man and a woman, but if it's two men or two women, it becomes a huge deal, splashed all over the news.  It should be a private, personal matter, not something that's constantly in the public eye and debated on a national level.

I'm going to have to disagree with that. When you post something online, it becomes public knowledge. You can't take it back. As a Resident Assistant, I've dealt with this firsthand.

What you share online shapes people's opinions of you. If you post about explosions or shootings, someone will react. You can't just put that out there for the world to see. The internet is accessible to everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll get their updates. 

Obviously, the school didn't receive a direct bulletin from Myspace. Someone went to the school with the information, and they had to act. They can't ignore it, because what if something actually happens?

On the other hand, it's hard to know what's serious and what's not. Sometimes people joke around online, which can lead to misunderstandings. It could be a class project gone wrong, but it could also be something truly dangerous.

In this case, someone overheard a conversation at school and reported it. When they looked at the student's Facebook, they found things that seemed concerning. What was meant as a joke could be taken seriously given the situation.

When you post online, there's no real privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't post it. You can't control how people interpret it or take it seriously. I don't think school officials should be friending their students on social media and snooping through their profiles. But if someone brings something to their attention, they have to take it seriously.

I don't think they should be monitoring phone calls, texts, or instant messages unless something specific is brought to their attention.

I also think it's wrong for teachers to create fake profiles to befriend students. That's just as invasive. As an RA, I don't want to know what my residents are doing in their personal lives. I don't want to see their pictures of them drinking or partying on Facebook. It's not my place to know, and I don't want that kind of connection.

I feel like this war has dragged on way too long.  At the beginning, I thought the goal was good – to bring democracy to a country that didn't have a fair political system. But I think we've lost sight of that original purpose. Now, it seems like we're just fighting for the sake of fighting, to prove we're a superpower. I also think the original reasons for going to war might have been questionable, considering the history between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein. If the goal was truly to bring democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a justifiable reason. But I don't think that's the case anymore.  

It feels like our purpose has become muddled over time. It's like we're still at war just to be at war, desperate for a decisive victory. I believe we made our point in the first few months, but it's been years, and it just feels excessive. 

Honestly, at this point, their government and officials need to figure things out on their own. We've been pouring billions of dollars into this war while neglecting our own problems here at home – poverty, failing infrastructure, healthcare – things that desperately need funding. It's a drain on our economy, and the money could be better spent elsewhere. 

We don't need to be at war forever. There comes a point where we need to step back and let other countries handle their own affairs. We have our own issues to address, and it's time to focus on them.

Can I ask a question to make sure I understand?  Uh, it was stopped because someone looked online and found that there was, like, some concerning information?

Okay.

Um, no, I don't think that's an invasion of privacy. On sites like Myspace, I mean, if you post something on the internet, it's pretty much out there for everyone to see. And I get that on Myspace you need someone else to be a member to see your profile. You might need to be friends with them or something. But if that's the case, you've already given that person permission to see your profile. So,

anyway, anytime you put something on the internet, you should know a lot of people will see it. So, if I think it's good that someone saw that information and was able to stop something bad from happening.

Hmm.

Um, that's tough. Because, obviously, you can't have one person watching everyone's profiles all day to prevent something bad. But then it becomes discriminatory if they start targeting "bad kids" and looking through their profiles.

Um, I don't think it would be right to have someone's job be to look at people's profiles. But I guess it depends on the situation. Like, did they stumble across the information randomly, or were they actively looking for evidence that someone was planning something? I don't really know.

Sure. Um, well, I don't use Myspace personally, but I have a Facebook. I do worry that there are creepy people out there who can see things about me. I saw something on TV once about this guy who just wanted to show how easy it was to get information. He went onto a girl's profile and got her screen name right away and started IM-ing her. He got her to meet him in less than a minute. And, personally, I definitely wouldn't meet with someone like that.  But I've had people in my classes I don't recognize their screen names, but they IM me and know it's me. It's creepy because they know your interests, what you look like, sometimes even your class schedule. They know where you are during the day and who your friends are. They see all sorts of photos. I try to limit what I put up there, but at the same time, the whole point of having a Facebook is to communicate with friends. I don't want to limit it too much. It's a tricky issue because I only accept people I know. But you never really know who can see what.

Hmm.

Uh, well, I heard my roommate talking about how her high school had a problem with students having Myspace, and they banned it. That seemed a little strange to me. I wasn't sure how school officials had the right to tell their students they couldn't have Myspace.  

I don't know if that's really a privacy issue, but I'm not sure how they had the right to tell people they couldn't. That's the only other thought I have.

I feel kind of hypocritical talking about the Iraq War. I hate to just jump on the bandwagon of people who say they were against it from the start. But, honestly, it's pretty clear now that it was a bad idea.  It seems like everyone agrees, except maybe those in the government who don't want to admit they were wrong.  Look at the polls – in the US, Iraq, and around the world, 75 to 80% of people think the war was a mistake.  Even a lot of the American troops over there think we should pull out within a year.  

It just feels like a complete disaster, from before we even went in to now.  Pulling out will probably be a disaster too,  There's no easy answer when it comes to the Middle East. It's just such a clash of cultures – the US and the Middle East are so different.  I think our government has this idea that they can just impose democracy on a place where it doesn't naturally fit.  

Sure, Saddam Hussein was a bad guy, but invading a country that's going to turn into a mess like this feels wrong.  It's like quicksand.  I honestly don't know what to say about it.  There doesn't seem to be any good reason to stay there any longer.  

I'm sure the administration has some hopeful plans for why staying is better, but I haven't heard anything convincing.  If they wanted to pull out gradually over a year or so, I wouldn't mind that, but just staying feels wrong.  

It's crazy to me that 80% of Iraqis want us to leave within a year, and a quarter of them want us to leave now. They're the ones we're trying to help, and they're telling us to leave! Maybe they know best.  If we ask them what they want, and they say leave, then we can't really blame ourselves if things go wrong afterwards.  At least we'll be able to say we tried to do what they wanted.  We might not ever be the "good guys" in the Middle East, but at least it would be better than where we are now.

I definitely think gender discrimination is still a problem in the United States. It's not just about women, though. It seems to depend on the specific field you're in. For example, women often face a "glass ceiling" where, even though equality is supposedly a thing, men might struggle to work under a female boss because of how society's been shaped for so long. So, a woman might have all the qualifications for a higher position, but the board might not promote her because historically, it's not common to see women in leadership roles.  

It's similar for men, though. Think about fields like fashion or staying home as a parent. It's unusual to see a stay-at-home dad. People often judge that because society expects men to be the breadwinners.  It can be tough on them if they want to be the primary caregiver while their wife works, even if it works well for their family. 

In the fashion industry, straight men sometimes face skepticism because people assume they don't "get" fashion since it's often associated with a particular lifestyle. It's like, "How can you know what women want if you don't live like us?" 

So, it really depends on the industry. I think there's definitely gender discrimination in the U.S., but it's changing slowly. Women are taking on more leadership roles, and stay-at-home dads are becoming more accepted. 

It's all about pushing forward gradually. If we try to force change too quickly, people will resist. We've made progress, and we just need to keep going at this pace.

So, they didn't actually legalize it, they decriminalized it.  That means it's no longer a criminal offense, more like a traffic ticket.  You get cited instead of arrested and hauled in.  I think if someone gets caught and cited, they still face those job interview problems and other downsides that come with a drug charge, even though it's not as serious.  A lot of people worry about those future consequences, especially kids. But at the same time, think about how much money it costs to arrest, book, and hold people, plus all the court appearances and public defenders.  It's a ton of money!  Municipalities with financial problems might be hesitant to decriminalize even if it frees up funds for things like schools, social programs, and food banks.  Some communities are just against marijuana, no matter what. But in places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, I think it's fine. They probably have more money now to spend on important things.  It's important because we don't want marijuana to be everywhere, like cigarettes sold in gas stations.  People smoking everywhere would be a mess. Plus, it's still kind of taboo in many places, so it would be awkward to see it so readily available.  I'm not sure about the volume, but I think alcohol is worse for your motor skills, but marijuana can mess with people's lives more.  Both have downsides, but people react differently to substances. Some people are more moderate, while others go overboard.  It's hard to generalize because everyone's different.

You know, I'd say Catholicism has its good points and its bad. 

 On one hand, they're really rooted in tradition, and that can be a good thing. Traditions give you a sense of history and belonging. But on the other hand, they can be so stuck in their ways.  It feels like they expect everyone to follow their rules perfectly, and if you don't, they kinda look down on you. 

Like, for example, my dad was Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic. They wouldn't even let them get married in the Catholic Church just because of his religion. That doesn't seem very loving or accepting to me. 

It's like they preach about loving everyone, but then they don't really practice what they preach. They tell you to do certain things, but then their actions contradict those teachings. It feels outdated and hypocritical. 

I think allowing priests to marry could be a good change, but I don't think it would stop those who are going to hurt children from doing so. It's a separate issue altogether. Pedophilia isn't about being married or not. It's a serious problem that needs to be addressed in a different way.

I'm still trying to figure out this whole debate about gay marriage.  I don't think either side is completely right or wrong, but it's definitely one of the toughest issues we're facing.  It's so tangled up with the separation of church and state and how we define marriage itself, which is really hard to do without upsetting people.

I think civil unions are a good idea. I'm not sure if the government should define marriage since it's seen as a religious sacrament. After all, the government doesn't care how people worship or if they're baptized, right?

If you're married, it should just be treated as a civil union by the government. It's about two people coming together. Whether it's a religious ceremony or not shouldn't matter.

I think if all the states can agree on a fair solution, they should push for it to become federal law.  But amending the constitution to ban gay marriage is just crazy.  The constitution shouldn't be changed for something like this.  It's a big deal for some people, but not big enough to warrant a constitutional amendment.

You know, growing up in a Christian household, the topic of homosexuality is a bit complicated for me. I have lots of gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I do believe they should have the right to marry.  I think it's something each state should decide on its own, rather than having the president make a national law about it.

It seems like states lean either Democratic or Republican, and that naturally influences their stance on gay marriage. Democratic states tend to be more supportive, and if you choose to live in one of those states, you're accepting their views. 

My personal feeling is that everyone, regardless of sexual orientation, deserves equal opportunities.  So, allowing states to decide on this issue feels like the fairest approach.

I'm not a fan of the idea of President Bush deciding that the whole country should be against gay marriage. Each state should have the freedom to choose what's right for them. He doesn't live in every single state, so he shouldn't get to dictate how they run their own affairs.

Plus, he's leaving office soon, and a Democratic president might lift the ban. It would just create a constantly changing back-and-forth.  It's best to let each state make its own decision, as they're the ones who will ultimately have to live with the consequences.

I don't really agree with that idea.  Myspace is meant to be public, like a bulletin board.  If you post something there, you have to understand people will see it, whether it's the school or not.  

So, if they found something on there, I think they had a right to see it.  Even if they weren't using the school's name, they could have easily accessed it from home.

Look, if they're using the internet to stop school shootings, to protect students - that's their job, right?  I think it's okay if it means keeping everyone safe.

It's different if they're just snooping around looking for kids who are drinking or smoking. That feels more like an invasion of privacy. But if they're trying to prevent something bad from happening, I don't see it as a problem.  

It's just like how we have to be careful about what we post online in general. Everything is out there forever. You never know when something you said online could come back to bite you later. It's just how the world works now.

I think it's like this: if you're posting something on Myspace and don't want anyone to see it, don't post it!

It's my opinion that if it helps keep the school safe, like what happened in those drills we did after 9/11, then it's worth it. Parents want to drop their kids off at school and know they're safe.

Okay, so, about the war… at first, I was totally on board, especially after 9/11 hit close to home. I wanted revenge, to make them pay for what they did.  Looking back, though, I think our emotions got the best of us. We jumped in without really thinking things through, unprepared and without a solid plan. It feels like it backfired in a big way.

I used to be all for it, but now I'm totally against it. I don't think it's accomplished anything. It seems like those people over there are too busy fighting each other to actually hurt us. I mean, if they can't even get along with each other, what makes us think we can fix things?

Honestly, 9/11 kind of numbed me to what's happening over there. I just don't care anymore. I feel like they're not even human sometimes, just constantly fighting and tearing each other apart. They can't seem to solve their own problems.

We went into the war unprepared. We didn't know what to expect, and war for them is different than it is for us. It's brutal and savage. They don't seem interested in making their country better; they just want us out. And maybe that's okay.   

I think we were just hyped up and looking for revenge. President Bush probably felt pressured to declare war on Iraq because the people wanted it after 9/11.  I understand where he was coming from – we couldn't just let them get away with it. But I think we could have found a better way.

We didn't have a clear plan for what to do once we were there, and there wasn't much unity. It felt like we were just going in blindly. That's probably why we haven't made much progress.  I think we went in with a lot of emotion and anger, and that's what we created over there.

Honestly, I don't think it's our place to change those people. They've always been like this, and I doubt anything will ever change. I don't see the point of staying there forever.  We're not making enough progress, and it's probably just hurting us more than helping.

transformed_texts:
I think the Catholic Church could benefit from some changes, especially in how they view certain issues.  I've heard that the Church is losing followers, and I think it might be because they aren't very accepting of things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. The Church has strong opinions on these topics, and while that's understandable, their stances feel a bit outdated.

If they were more open to modern ways of thinking, I think they wouldn't have to worry as much about losing people.  Many people are starting to disagree with the Church's views on these subjects, particularly when it comes to things like abortion and gay marriage.  Someone who believes in those things might not feel comfortable in a community that condemns them. For example, if someone supports abortion rights, they might not feel welcome in a Church that considers it completely wrong. Same goes for those who support gay marriage.

Personally, I don't see why they can't have female priests or allow priests to be married.  I'm not sure if those changes would have prevented past scandals, but it seems like a reasonable idea.

The Church says priests are "married" to God and devote their lives to Him, but everyone else has a job and a family life.  Why can't priests have both?

I'm not against gay marriage. I believe people shouldn't be judged for who they love, whether they're born that way or not. It's not a choice anyone makes. So, I think it's unfair to say that a man and a woman can marry, but two people of the same sex can't. Honestly, I haven't given this topic a lot of thought, but I definitely think it's wrong to deny same-sex couples the right to marry.   

I think being gay is just part of who a person is, like being straight. People aren't choosing to be gay, it's how they're born. It's not right to hold someone responsible for their sexual orientation.

I also don't think the federal government should be involved. It's not a legal or moral issue, in my opinion. I don't think it's appropriate for the government to dictate who can and can't marry. It's a personal matter.

It just seems wrong to me to treat gay people differently or make them feel like they've made a wrong choice.  They should be treated equally and allowed to live their lives how they choose.

I truly believe that gay marriage should be legal. Honestly, there's not a solid reason against it.  Some folks worry that gay couples threaten traditional families, but that's just not true. It's totally different.  Think of it like two sides of the same coin, heads and tails are different, but they're still connected.  Gay relationships are similar to straight ones, with the same hopes, dreams, and challenges.   

There are also important rights at stake.  For example, if you're in a gay relationship, your partner might not be able to make medical decisions for you if you're sick, or even visit you in the hospital, because they aren't legally recognized as family. That seems unfair if you're committed to spending your life with someone.  

And studies show that gay couples are just as successful as straight couples. They have the same things that make relationships work: love, communication, and support.  It's about the relationship, not who's involved.

The core issue is that people often get hung up on the idea of a religious ceremony. Gay couples aren't demanding a church wedding, they're asking for a legal document from the government: a marriage certificate.  If we separate church and state, then this shouldn't be a problem. It's like saying you can't have a civil union because it goes against your religion, but then you're okay with a marriage license. It's "separate but unequal."

I hear worries about adoption and community impact, especially about how kids raised by gay parents will be treated.  But ultimately, loving parents raise happy, well-adjusted kids, regardless of their sexual orientation. It's about good parenting, not about who the parents are.

I think the federal government should definitely step in and make gay marriage legal everywhere.  It's about basic equality. President Bush has strong beliefs about this issue, which seem connected to his views on abortion and stem cell research. Many arguments against gay marriage are based on religion, but morality is subjective and changes over time. Forcing one group's beliefs on everyone else is unfair and hypocritical, especially when we have a pledge of allegiance that includes "under God" yet oppose religious influence in government.

Some people believe being gay is a psychological defect or caused by childhood trauma, but the American Psychological Association has debunked that myth.  It's important to rely on science and research, not just personal opinions or cultural norms. If we all listened to experts and challenged our biases, the world would be a better place.

Okay, so I work in a hospital pharmacy during the summer, and it's made me think a lot about drugs.  I mean, just because something's illegal doesn't automatically mean it's bad. Take marijuana, for example.  It's illegal, but I think people should be able to use it for medical reasons. I'm not saying everyone should be smoking weed, but if it can help someone, why not?  It's not like those strong painkillers, like oxycodone, Vicodin, or Percocet, which are totally legal even though they can be addictive.  I see how those are helpful, so why not give marijuana a chance?  I think people get hung up on the stigma around marijuana, but it's not as harmful as everyone makes it out to be.  It's not like heroin or cocaine.  It wouldn't hurt to at least explore its potential benefits, especially for medical use. 

Maybe we should make it legal gradually, so people can learn to use it responsibly.  If we just keep demonizing it, it'll always be associated with bad things.  If we could change that image, maybe people would be more open to using it safely and for good.

I think the Catholic Church has changed to fit modern times. It's not as strict as it used to be. When I was younger, I went to church every Sunday dressed up in cute dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. I went to a private school, so I saw all my friends there on weekends.  Now that I'm older, they have a special mass for teenagers that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially in the summer, sometimes even coming straight from the beach. Even at the morning masses, where I used to always dress up, people wear jeans and khakis. It's a lot more relaxed.

I think that's the biggest change I've noticed. That's the church I know. I don't know about the church's internal politics, but that's the main thing that stands out to me.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests about pedophilia, I don't think allowing priests to marry or ordaining women would have stopped it. Some married men become pedophiles too, and their attraction to young children isn't caused by their marital status. It's the person, not their relationship status.

Becoming a priest is a choice, and there are other religions that allow priests to marry, like the one on the TV show "Seventh Heaven." If someone really wants to practice their faith and be married, they could consider a different religion.

(laughs)
You know, at first, I was okay with the idea of the Iraq War, but I think everyone was still shaken up from the 9/11 attacks. It felt like we went into Iraq with a bunch of justifications that didn't quite add up. The Bush administration kept tying the war to Osama Bin Laden and 9/11, saying Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. We now know that was all a lie.  That really bugs me, and the whole Iraq War just makes my blood boil.

It feels like the Bush administration straight-up lied to the American people, and they've never admitted it. Even Colin Powell, who gave that big speech at the UN, now says he wasn't really convinced by the evidence when he was presenting it. To me, that's a serious abuse of power. It's almost like an impeachable offense to lie to the people like that.  I think the Bush administration has completely disregarded the Constitution and has been trying to weaken it ever since 9/11. It seems like they came into office wanting to go to war.

There was this Treasury Secretary - I can't remember his name - who basically said that in his book after he got pushed out of his job. Seems like the younger Bush wanted revenge against Saddam Hussein because of his dad's administration, and he probably wanted to control Iraq's oil, too.  That's a pretty sneaky way to do things.

Look, I think the war has gone on long enough. Pulling out right now would probably create chaos, though, and more people would die.  There's this idea now of a coalition of countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia coming in to try and restore order, but I'm not sure that's a good idea either. It could cause even more problems because it'll mess with Iraq's sovereignty.

The news reports say that the Iraqi Parliament isn't really working. The Prime Minister doesn't seem to have any real power, and this guy, Muqtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting not long ago, now has at least 20 seats in Parliament. We're still dealing with all these different radical groups fighting for control, and it's causing a lot of tension.

(laughs)
I can't really say more about it without getting into some pretty sensitive stuff.

I'm not really sure what to say about the war in Iraq. It feels pointless because it wasn't even officially declared. It feels like it was just retaliation for 9/11, like we were trying to get back at Iraq because they were thought to be responsible.  I'm not really knowledgeable about the details of the war, but it seems like we're staying there to try and build a democracy, kind of like making Iraq another U.S. state, and also to access their oil. But staying there just makes everyone angry. 

Trying to force democracy on them is going to take forever, and if we leave, they'll be upset because things will be in chaos. It's a really tough situation. 

Honestly, I'm not even sure how I feel about it. I think maybe it's better to stay and try to help, but it's also wasting our resources and making our president look bad. 

It's like the Vietnam War, which was also an undeclared war and is now seen as meaningless. I worry that this war will be remembered the same way.  

There are families with sons and daughters in Iraq, and I want them to come home safe, but at the same time, we've disrupted their lives and culture. We're trying to force our way of life on them, which could make things worse and fuel more hatred towards the U.S. 

This whole situation is going to drag on for years and years.

I really don't think it's right for the government to make it legal or for a state to declare it as legal. I believe it's up to the churches because the Constitution clearly states separation of church and state. It's plainly written, and I feel that trying to enforce any kind of control over it would be going against what's already been established in the Constitution.  So, when people try to make it illegal, I think they're favoring one church's beliefs over others. As we can see, most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for in some areas like Boston.  But I don't think it's the government's place to decide what churches can and can't do. 

Separation of church and state is a key part of the Constitution and what allows for religious tolerance in the United States. Even though they were considering making an amendment, I think that would be completely wrong and contradictory to what's already been written. Plus, I believe it would be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I just don't think it's right.

I don't believe the federal government, or any government, should be involved in this issue. I don't understand why someone would push for this amendment unless it's because it goes against their personal beliefs as a Catholic. Like I said, his push for this amendment shows that he prefers one religion over others. I truly feel that it's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government officials. There isn't a good reason to support this amendment other than personal views. I don't see how it would impact the economy or anything else. In fact, it might have a positive impact on society.

Okay, so the war in Iraq...  I don't think the government was totally honest with us about why we went to war. They tried to tie it to 9/11, even though those two things weren't really connected. It felt like they were trying to use our anger after the attacks to justify the invasion, which started in 2003.

 Personally, I'm against war, especially starting wars preemptively.  This whole Iraq thing feels a lot like Vietnam. We should have learned from our mistakes there. 

So many American soldiers have died. They went in and just overthrew the Iraqi government, but they weren't prepared for what would happen next. They didn't understand the power vacuum and the chaos that would follow. They basically tried to install a democracy, similar to what they did in Vietnam, but it's  a long and tough process. 

You can't just force democracy on a country. It takes time, and it's messy. They made it seem like it would be a quick win, but it hasn't been. We've been there for years, and American troops are still dying. We're still trying to train Iraqi police and soldiers to take control of their own country. 

 It's a tough situation.  We've been there so long, how can we just leave now?  But how many more American lives are we willing to risk for this?  And honestly, it feels like this was more about oil than about democracy.  We knew Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but we haven't found any. Yet we're not doing anything about other countries with WMDs, like North Korea.  

I just hope it ends soon and that there's peace in Iraq someday.

Let me tell you, I've always been in favor of gay marriage. I truly believe it's a personal preference, something that science is increasingly showing might even have a biological basis rather than being just a social construct. It just doesn't seem right to deny people rights based on something they can't control.  It feels downright inhumane to me.  

I've always championed the cause of gay marriage. Politics and government shouldn't have a say in this. It's a personal matter, something that happens within families and communities.  

In my own neighborhood, there are a few openly gay couples who aren't married because they can't be. They live their lives just like any other family – walking dogs, going about their day. They're just like everyone else.

It's frustrating to see someone like Bush trying to play God and define marriage in a way that suits his beliefs. To me, it's completely ridiculous.

What I find interesting is that research suggests being gay might be linked to things happening in our brains, a biological predisposition rather than something learned from our environment. It's not about growing up with lots of sisters or a missing father figure. It's about who you are.

The whole situation is just strange. A couple can get married without anyone knowing if they're a man and a woman, but if it's two men or two women, it becomes a huge deal, splashed all over the news.  It should be a private, personal matter, not something that's constantly in the public eye and debated on a national level.

I'm going to have to disagree with that. When you post something online, it becomes public knowledge. You can't take it back. As a Resident Assistant, I've dealt with this firsthand.

What you share online shapes people's opinions of you. If you post about explosions or shootings, someone will react. You can't just put that out there for the world to see. The internet is accessible to everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll get their updates. 

Obviously, the school didn't receive a direct bulletin from Myspace. Someone went to the school with the information, and they had to act. They can't ignore it, because what if something actually happens?

On the other hand, it's hard to know what's serious and what's not. Sometimes people joke around online, which can lead to misunderstandings. It could be a class project gone wrong, but it could also be something truly dangerous.

In this case, someone overheard a conversation at school and reported it. When they looked at the student's Facebook, they found things that seemed concerning. What was meant as a joke could be taken seriously given the situation.

When you post online, there's no real privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't post it. You can't control how people interpret it or take it seriously. I don't think school officials should be friending their students on social media and snooping through their profiles. But if someone brings something to their attention, they have to take it seriously.

I don't think they should be monitoring phone calls, texts, or instant messages unless something specific is brought to their attention.

I also think it's wrong for teachers to create fake profiles to befriend students. That's just as invasive. As an RA, I don't want to know what my residents are doing in their personal lives. I don't want to see their pictures of them drinking or partying on Facebook. It's not my place to know, and I don't want that kind of connection.

I feel like this war has dragged on way too long.  At the beginning, I thought the goal was good – to bring democracy to a country that didn't have a fair political system. But I think we've lost sight of that original purpose. Now, it seems like we're just fighting for the sake of fighting, to prove we're a superpower. I also think the original reasons for going to war might have been questionable, considering the history between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein. If the goal was truly to bring democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a justifiable reason. But I don't think that's the case anymore.  

It feels like our purpose has become muddled over time. It's like we're still at war just to be at war, desperate for a decisive victory. I believe we made our point in the first few months, but it's been years, and it just feels excessive. 

Honestly, at this point, their government and officials need to figure things out on their own. We've been pouring billions of dollars into this war while neglecting our own problems here at home – poverty, failing infrastructure, healthcare – things that desperately need funding. It's a drain on our economy, and the money could be better spent elsewhere. 

We don't need to be at war forever. There comes a point where we need to step back and let other countries handle their own affairs. We have our own issues to address, and it's time to focus on them.

Can I ask a question to make sure I understand?  Uh, it was stopped because someone looked online and found that there was, like, some concerning information?

Okay.

Um, no, I don't think that's an invasion of privacy. On sites like Myspace, I mean, if you post something on the internet, it's pretty much out there for everyone to see. And I get that on Myspace you need someone else to be a member to see your profile. You might need to be friends with them or something. But if that's the case, you've already given that person permission to see your profile. So,

anyway, anytime you put something on the internet, you should know a lot of people will see it. So, if I think it's good that someone saw that information and was able to stop something bad from happening.

Hmm.

Um, that's tough. Because, obviously, you can't have one person watching everyone's profiles all day to prevent something bad. But then it becomes discriminatory if they start targeting "bad kids" and looking through their profiles.

Um, I don't think it would be right to have someone's job be to look at people's profiles. But I guess it depends on the situation. Like, did they stumble across the information randomly, or were they actively looking for evidence that someone was planning something? I don't really know.

Sure. Um, well, I don't use Myspace personally, but I have a Facebook. I do worry that there are creepy people out there who can see things about me. I saw something on TV once about this guy who just wanted to show how easy it was to get information. He went onto a girl's profile and got her screen name right away and started IM-ing her. He got her to meet him in less than a minute. And, personally, I definitely wouldn't meet with someone like that.  But I've had people in my classes I don't recognize their screen names, but they IM me and know it's me. It's creepy because they know your interests, what you look like, sometimes even your class schedule. They know where you are during the day and who your friends are. They see all sorts of photos. I try to limit what I put up there, but at the same time, the whole point of having a Facebook is to communicate with friends. I don't want to limit it too much. It's a tricky issue because I only accept people I know. But you never really know who can see what.

Hmm.

Uh, well, I heard my roommate talking about how her high school had a problem with students having Myspace, and they banned it. That seemed a little strange to me. I wasn't sure how school officials had the right to tell their students they couldn't have Myspace.  

I don't know if that's really a privacy issue, but I'm not sure how they had the right to tell people they couldn't. That's the only other thought I have.

I feel kind of hypocritical talking about the Iraq War. I hate to just jump on the bandwagon of people who say they were against it from the start. But, honestly, it's pretty clear now that it was a bad idea.  It seems like everyone agrees, except maybe those in the government who don't want to admit they were wrong.  Look at the polls – in the US, Iraq, and around the world, 75 to 80% of people think the war was a mistake.  Even a lot of the American troops over there think we should pull out within a year.  

It just feels like a complete disaster, from before we even went in to now.  Pulling out will probably be a disaster too,  There's no easy answer when it comes to the Middle East. It's just such a clash of cultures – the US and the Middle East are so different.  I think our government has this idea that they can just impose democracy on a place where it doesn't naturally fit.  

Sure, Saddam Hussein was a bad guy, but invading a country that's going to turn into a mess like this feels wrong.  It's like quicksand.  I honestly don't know what to say about it.  There doesn't seem to be any good reason to stay there any longer.  

I'm sure the administration has some hopeful plans for why staying is better, but I haven't heard anything convincing.  If they wanted to pull out gradually over a year or so, I wouldn't mind that, but just staying feels wrong.  

It's crazy to me that 80% of Iraqis want us to leave within a year, and a quarter of them want us to leave now. They're the ones we're trying to help, and they're telling us to leave! Maybe they know best.  If we ask them what they want, and they say leave, then we can't really blame ourselves if things go wrong afterwards.  At least we'll be able to say we tried to do what they wanted.  We might not ever be the "good guys" in the Middle East, but at least it would be better than where we are now.

I definitely think gender discrimination is still a problem in the United States. It's not just about women, though. It seems to depend on the specific field you're in. For example, women often face a "glass ceiling" where, even though equality is supposedly a thing, men might struggle to work under a female boss because of how society's been shaped for so long. So, a woman might have all the qualifications for a higher position, but the board might not promote her because historically, it's not common to see women in leadership roles.  

It's similar for men, though. Think about fields like fashion or staying home as a parent. It's unusual to see a stay-at-home dad. People often judge that because society expects men to be the breadwinners.  It can be tough on them if they want to be the primary caregiver while their wife works, even if it works well for their family. 

In the fashion industry, straight men sometimes face skepticism because people assume they don't "get" fashion since it's often associated with a particular lifestyle. It's like, "How can you know what women want if you don't live like us?" 

So, it really depends on the industry. I think there's definitely gender discrimination in the U.S., but it's changing slowly. Women are taking on more leadership roles, and stay-at-home dads are becoming more accepted. 

It's all about pushing forward gradually. If we try to force change too quickly, people will resist. We've made progress, and we just need to keep going at this pace.

So, they didn't actually legalize it, they decriminalized it.  That means it's no longer a criminal offense, more like a traffic ticket.  You get cited instead of arrested and hauled in.  I think if someone gets caught and cited, they still face those job interview problems and other downsides that come with a drug charge, even though it's not as serious.  A lot of people worry about those future consequences, especially kids. But at the same time, think about how much money it costs to arrest, book, and hold people, plus all the court appearances and public defenders.  It's a ton of money!  Municipalities with financial problems might be hesitant to decriminalize even if it frees up funds for things like schools, social programs, and food banks.  Some communities are just against marijuana, no matter what. But in places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, I think it's fine. They probably have more money now to spend on important things.  It's important because we don't want marijuana to be everywhere, like cigarettes sold in gas stations.  People smoking everywhere would be a mess. Plus, it's still kind of taboo in many places, so it would be awkward to see it so readily available.  I'm not sure about the volume, but I think alcohol is worse for your motor skills, but marijuana can mess with people's lives more.  Both have downsides, but people react differently to substances. Some people are more moderate, while others go overboard.  It's hard to generalize because everyone's different.

You know, I'd say Catholicism has its good points and its bad. 

 On one hand, they're really rooted in tradition, and that can be a good thing. Traditions give you a sense of history and belonging. But on the other hand, they can be so stuck in their ways.  It feels like they expect everyone to follow their rules perfectly, and if you don't, they kinda look down on you. 

Like, for example, my dad was Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic. They wouldn't even let them get married in the Catholic Church just because of his religion. That doesn't seem very loving or accepting to me. 

It's like they preach about loving everyone, but then they don't really practice what they preach. They tell you to do certain things, but then their actions contradict those teachings. It feels outdated and hypocritical. 

I think allowing priests to marry could be a good change, but I don't think it would stop those who are going to hurt children from doing so. It's a separate issue altogether. Pedophilia isn't about being married or not. It's a serious problem that needs to be addressed in a different way.

I'm still trying to figure out this whole debate about gay marriage.  I don't think either side is completely right or wrong, but it's definitely one of the toughest issues we're facing.  It's so tangled up with the separation of church and state and how we define marriage itself, which is really hard to do without upsetting people.

I think civil unions are a good idea. I'm not sure if the government should define marriage since it's seen as a religious sacrament. After all, the government doesn't care how people worship or if they're baptized, right?

If you're married, it should just be treated as a civil union by the government. It's about two people coming together. Whether it's a religious ceremony or not shouldn't matter.

I think if all the states can agree on a fair solution, they should push for it to become federal law.  But amending the constitution to ban gay marriage is just crazy.  The constitution shouldn't be changed for something like this.  It's a big deal for some people, but not big enough to warrant a constitutional amendment.

You know, growing up in a Christian household, the topic of homosexuality is a bit complicated for me. I have lots of gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I do believe they should have the right to marry.  I think it's something each state should decide on its own, rather than having the president make a national law about it.

It seems like states lean either Democratic or Republican, and that naturally influences their stance on gay marriage. Democratic states tend to be more supportive, and if you choose to live in one of those states, you're accepting their views. 

My personal feeling is that everyone, regardless of sexual orientation, deserves equal opportunities.  So, allowing states to decide on this issue feels like the fairest approach.

I'm not a fan of the idea of President Bush deciding that the whole country should be against gay marriage. Each state should have the freedom to choose what's right for them. He doesn't live in every single state, so he shouldn't get to dictate how they run their own affairs.

Plus, he's leaving office soon, and a Democratic president might lift the ban. It would just create a constantly changing back-and-forth.  It's best to let each state make its own decision, as they're the ones who will ultimately have to live with the consequences.

I don't really agree with that idea.  Myspace is meant to be public, like a bulletin board.  If you post something there, you have to understand people will see it, whether it's the school or not.  

So, if they found something on there, I think they had a right to see it.  Even if they weren't using the school's name, they could have easily accessed it from home.

Look, if they're using the internet to stop school shootings, to protect students - that's their job, right?  I think it's okay if it means keeping everyone safe.

It's different if they're just snooping around looking for kids who are drinking or smoking. That feels more like an invasion of privacy. But if they're trying to prevent something bad from happening, I don't see it as a problem.  

It's just like how we have to be careful about what we post online in general. Everything is out there forever. You never know when something you said online could come back to bite you later. It's just how the world works now.

I think it's like this: if you're posting something on Myspace and don't want anyone to see it, don't post it!

It's my opinion that if it helps keep the school safe, like what happened in those drills we did after 9/11, then it's worth it. Parents want to drop their kids off at school and know they're safe.

Okay, so, about the war… at first, I was totally on board, especially after 9/11 hit close to home. I wanted revenge, to make them pay for what they did.  Looking back, though, I think our emotions got the best of us. We jumped in without really thinking things through, unprepared and without a solid plan. It feels like it backfired in a big way.

I used to be all for it, but now I'm totally against it. I don't think it's accomplished anything. It seems like those people over there are too busy fighting each other to actually hurt us. I mean, if they can't even get along with each other, what makes us think we can fix things?

Honestly, 9/11 kind of numbed me to what's happening over there. I just don't care anymore. I feel like they're not even human sometimes, just constantly fighting and tearing each other apart. They can't seem to solve their own problems.

We went into the war unprepared. We didn't know what to expect, and war for them is different than it is for us. It's brutal and savage. They don't seem interested in making their country better; they just want us out. And maybe that's okay.   

I think we were just hyped up and looking for revenge. President Bush probably felt pressured to declare war on Iraq because the people wanted it after 9/11.  I understand where he was coming from – we couldn't just let them get away with it. But I think we could have found a better way.

We didn't have a clear plan for what to do once we were there, and there wasn't much unity. It felt like we were just going in blindly. That's probably why we haven't made much progress.  I think we went in with a lot of emotion and anger, and that's what we created over there.

Honestly, I don't think it's our place to change those people. They've always been like this, and I doubt anything will ever change. I don't see the point of staying there forever.  We're not making enough progress, and it's probably just hurting us more than helping.
